'Ivi Inc.' commonly just 'Ivi', is a Seattle-based <ref></ref> American
corporation that offers a software application<ref></ref> providing live video
streaming over the Internet for a flat rate.<ref></ref>

'Ivi' (pronounced 'ivy')<ref></ref> is the first online cable
company.<ref></ref> The Ivi TV player is a downloaded software application that
runs on Windows, Macintosh, or GNU/Linux
computers<ref></ref><ref>https://www.ivi.tv/player</ref> offering live
television on the Internet.

««Legal »» 'Ivi' is currently in the midst of a copyright lawsuit ([[WPIX, Inc.
v. ivi, Inc.]]) filed on September 28, 2010<ref></ref> with several major US TV
networks.<ref></ref> This case has been deemed "The Case That Could Finally Put
Live TV on the Internet" by Forbes, since the outcome of the 'Ivi' case will
determine if shows streamed over the Internet will be able to compete with Cable
and Satellite Television.<ref></ref> A group of four public interest groups; The
Electronic Frontier Foundation, Media Access Project, Open Technology
Initiative, and Public Knowledge have filed an amicus curiae brief in support of
'Ivi'.<ref></ref> stating "The law does not favor larger or better-funded
entities over new or smaller ones, nor is it a bludgeon to be used by large,
entrenched interests to eliminate nascent competitors."<ref></ref>

On February 22, 2011 District Judge Naomi Buchwald granted an injunction,
shutting down most of the broadcast stations carried by 'Ivi'.<ref
name="paidcontentivi"></ref> 'Ivi' and its CEO argued that 'Ivi' fits the
definition of a "cable system" under section 111(f) of U.S. Copyright Law. The
plaintiffs, US TV Networks, are arguing that 'Ivi' doesn't fit this
description.<ref name="paidcontentivi"/> The relevant part of copyright law
reads "A cable system is a facility that “makes secondary transmissions of such
signals or programs by wires, cables, microwave, or 'other communications
channels' to subscribing members of the
public.”".<ref>[http://www.copyright.gov/title17/92chap1.html#111 Section 111 of
Copyright Law]</ref> 'Ivi' immediately filed an appeal to the Second Circuit
Court of Appeals,<ref></ref><ref></ref> but the court affirmed the district
court's decision.<ref>http://courtlistener.com/ca2/591W/wpix-v-ivi/</ref>
